docs.lead_paragraph: NEW LONDON, Conn., June 20 — Prosecutors opened a Coast Guard cadet's court-martial on Tuesday by saying he was controlling and preyed on weak women for sexual gratification, while defense lawyers said he was a victim of a conspiracy much like the Salem Witch Trials.

headline.main: Testimony Begins in Coast Guard Cadet's Trial on Rape Charges

docs.lead_paragraph: Science Times readers respond to last week's article about the campaign to promote breast-feeding.
docs.snippet: Science Times readers respond to last week's article about the campaign to promote breast-feeding.

docs.lead_paragraph: Science Times received an extraordinary outpouring of letters -- more than 100, pro and con -- over last week's article ''Breast-Feed or Else,'' about the public health campaign to promote breast-feeding and discourage formula and bottles. A sampling follows; others are online at nytimes.com/science. To the Editor: As a breast-feeding mother, I appreciated your thoughtful, important article ''Breast-Feed or Else'' (June 13). It is important to add that the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends breast-feeding not only for six months, but exclusively for six months, and for as long thereafter as mutually desired by mother and child. Further, studies indicate that the composition of the breast milk becomes better over time, contrary to the popular belief that after six months it offers little benefit. Cammie Kim Lin New York To the Editor: When my son was born, I was intent on breast-feeding, regardless of the difficulties. But even with the help of my pediatrician and a lactation consultant, we needed to supplement with formula.
docs.abstract: Fourteen letters on June 13 article about breast-feeding infants; many cite need for changes in American culture, workplace and health care to enable mothers to give babies advantages of breast milk; some hold that article was demeaning to mothers who for variety of reasons cannot breast-feed; photo

docs.lead_paragraph: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., June 15 — Lurking behind the Wisteria Lane facade of suburban prosperity, many middle-class Long Islanders are barely hanging on and others are suffering in pockets of poverty, disease and dysfunction, a new report says.

headline.main: Report Finds Hardship Amid Plenty on L.I.
headline.print_headline: Report Finds Hardship Amid Plenty on L.I.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's the last day of Mad Scientist Week, and I'd like to discuss the ultimate mad scientist's experiment: what would happen if we crossed humans with chimpanzees?

headline.main: Mad Science: Crossing Human With Chimp

docs.abstract: It's the last day of Mad Scientist Week, and I'd like to discuss the ultimate mad scientist's experiment: what would happen if we crossed humans with chimpanzees? Along with cloning, this is one of those ideas that has exercised many a science-fiction writer, and fascinated their readers - perhaps because it raises so many questions [...]
